BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind a dangerous avalanche situation will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of new snow at low altitude. In some localities strong wind at low altitude.
Between approximately 2000 and 2300 m: As a consequence of sleet and the strong wind, a critical avalanche situation will develop in the course of the day.
Medium-sized to large natural avalanches are likely, also in case of releases originating from steep starting zones at high altitude.
Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and in isolated cases endanger exposed transportation routes.

As a consequence of new snow and wind from southwesterly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs will form. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular above approximately 2000 m.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
The conditions are dangerous for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Thus far the wind has been strong to storm force in some localities over a wide area. The new snow will become increasingly prone to triggering. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly at elevated altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area various wind slab layers are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2000 m only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind and new snow: The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The avalanches can in isolated cases reach large size. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. 5 to 15 cm of snow will fall. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 1000 m snow will fall in some localities. The large surface-area wind slabs can be released easily or naturally on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can over a wide area be released by small loads and reach large size. In the course of the day these will increase in size additionally. Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some new snow at low altitude. In some localities strong wind at low altitude.
As a consequence of sleet and the strong wind, a sometimes critical avalanche situation will develop in the course of the day.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are likely, also in case of releases originating from steep starting zones at high altitude.
Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and in isolated cases endanger exposed transportation routes.

As a consequence of new snow and wind from southwesterly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs will form. Above the tree line the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
The conditions are precarious for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Thus far the wind has been strong to storm force in some localities over a wide area. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly at elevated altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2000 m only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind and new snow: The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 2200 m. The avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. These avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. Below approximately 2200 m medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 15 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2500 m. The strong wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at high altitude. Below approximately 2200 m moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2200 m. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Below approximately 2200 m small to medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2500 m. The southwesterly wind will transport the new snow. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The rain will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2000 m. In all altitude zones only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A little new snow at low altitude.

As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from southwesterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Above the tree line the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.

Small to medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the last two days the wind was moderate to strong over a wide area.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 1900 m only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the last few days at elevated altitudes. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2200 m. The more recent wind slabs are to be bypassed in very steep terrain. As a consequence of the rain, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase a little in all regions at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable and has a loosely bonded surface. This applies in particular in shady places that are protected from the wind. In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year. The rain will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow will fall until Friday above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, wind slabs will form in particular in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially on very steep slopes above approximately 2000 m.
At high altitude the wind slabs are larger.
Fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases.
Isolated whumpfing sounds can indicate the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be prone to triggering in some places. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 1900 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted and weak. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are clearly recognisable. They represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Especially on wind-loaded slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some places wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
In some localities snowfall.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise and prone to triggering. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Caution is to be exercised in all aspects in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. These can be released easily in some cases above the tree line. This also applies in areas close to the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided as far as possible. Even a small avalanche can sweep winter sport participants along and give rise to falls. In isolated cases avalanches are medium-sized.

In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes below approximately 2300 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from southwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The wind slabs of Wednesday are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. The somewhat older wind slabs are unlikely to be released now.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1300 m. The wind slabs of Wednesday remain prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise and prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. These can be released easily in some cases above the tree line. This also applies in areas close to the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided as far as possible. In isolated cases avalanches are medium-sized. Even a small avalanche can sweep winter sport participants along and give rise to falls.

In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from southwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The fresh wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.

Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall in particular in the north. The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the widespread mostly small wind slabs represent the main danger. In particular on steep shady slopes medium-sized natural avalanches must be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude brittle wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack. The old snowpack will be quite stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are clearly recognisable. They represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The older wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In particular on very steep slopes more mostly small avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The meteorological conditions facilitated a strengthening of the snowpack.
Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
In some localities snowfall.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow will be deposited on the quite favourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 1200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow above approximately 1500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small avalanches are not ruled out.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1500 m hardly any snow is lying. Above approximately 1500 m a little snow is lying. The snowpack remains generally stable. Especially gullies and bowls are precarious. Here small wind slabs formed. These are shallow and can be released in isolated cases. These avalanche prone locations are rather rare.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering.
